objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer

objinfo.numberobj:
18
The word "Preludium," printed from a separate copperplate (designated as plate e) at the top of object 3 in some copies, was not printed in this copy. Object 13 is in the second state, with one tail on the snake, lower left. Objects 4 and 9 in this copy are lithographic reproductions, perhaps based on copy F. For details, see Thomas V. Lange, "Two Forged Plates in America copy B," and Joseph Viscomi, "Facsimile or Forgery? An Examination of America , Plates 4 and 9, Copy B," Blake: An Illustrated Quarterly 16.4 (spring 1983): 212-23.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 23.8 x 17.4 cm. and 23.1 x 16.3 cm.
objinfo.medium: Relief etching, with extensive white-line etching on objects 1, 8, 10, 11, and 15, and gray wash on object 2 (the title page). Most other objects bear at least touches of white-line etching/engraving. Objects 4 and 9 are lithographic reproductions; see the note following Number of Objects, above. There are inscriptions and sketches, not by Blake, on the versos of objects 1 (bound as a recto because object 1, the frontispiece, faces object 2, the title page), 2, and 17. The small drawing (a branch or vine with many thin leaves) on the back of object 1 appears under an inscription, "Mary Taylor London." This drawing is in the same brown ink, and appears to have been executed with the same pen, as the inscription. This drawing is almost certainly by Taylor. The ink drawing of a winged human figure, probably an angel, on the verso of object 2 might be by Taylor, or by C. H. Tatham, the first owner of the volume, or by Albert George Dew-Smith, who owned the volume from c. 1874 to 1878 (see the note on Provenance, below). The pencil sketches on the verso of object 17 may be by Tatham or Dew-Smith. They include two heads in profile, a head and torso in profile, possibly a duck, and a landscape including a walking figure, a tree, and a building or gravestone with a cross above. These inscriptions and drawings are presented here as Related Works in the Archive. For the pen and ink sketch added to object 5, see the Editors' Notes on object 5.
objinfo.watermark: 1794 / J Whatman The watermark appears on the leaves bearing objects 1, 5, 8, 11, and 18.
objinfo.pennednumbers: none Pencil numbers, top right and bottom left, are not by Blake.
objinfo.binding: citron morocco by F. Bedford Object 1, the frontispiece, is bound facing object 2, the title page.
objinfo.stabholes: Stabbed once through three holes, 6.5 and 7.7 cm. apart. Stabbed again through three holes, 10.7 aand 12.9 cm. apart.

desc.objtitle:
,
object 2 verso: full view including drawings (Bentley 2, Erdman ii, Keynes ii)

objnote.p: On the verso of object 2 there is a pen and ink drawing of a winged human figure (probably an angel), a pin-prick pattern in the form of an "S," and an inscription, none of them by Blake. The drawing may have been executed by Mary Taylor (see the inscription lower left on the verso of object 1), or by C. H. Tatham, the first owner of the volume, or by Albert George Dew-Smith, who owned the volume from c. 1874 to 1878 (see the note on Provenance on the Copy Information page). The same hand, probably using the same ink, probably executed the drawing on object 5 (see the Editors' Notes on object 5).

illustration.illusobjdesc: A pen and ink drawing of a winged human figure, probably an angel, appears upside down at upper right. A signature and a pin-prick pattern in the form of an S appear at lower right.

component.illusobjdesc: A pen and ink drawing of a winged human figure, probably an angel, appears upside down at upper right.
A signature and a pin-prick pattern in the form of an "S" appear at lower right.

lg.l: mary Jane This inscription, not by Blake, appears vertically at lower right.

Tatham, the first owner of the volume, or by Albert George Dew-Smith, who owned the volume from c. 1874 to 1878 (see the note on Provenance on the Copy Information page). The same hand, probably using the same ink, probably executed the drawing on object 5 (see the Editors' Notes on object 5).

desc.objtitle:
,
object 17 verso: full view including drawings (Bentley 17, Erdman 15, Keynes 15)

objnote.p: These pencil sketches are not by Blake. They may have been executed by by C. H. Tatham, the first owner of the volume, or by Albert George Dew-Smith, who owned the volume from c. 1874 to 1878 (see the note on Provenance on the Copy Information page).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Near the left margin of the leaf appear, arranged vertically, two human heads and the upper body and head of a figure, presumably male, in profile. The two uppermost figures have curly hair. The lowermost figure wears a top hat; he appears to be striding to the left, and may be carrying a bouquet of flowers. Above the heads are some rounded forms that may be a bird, perhaps a duck, standing and facing right. Near the bottom margin is a landscape including a walking figure, a tree, and a building or gravestone with three crosses.

component.illusobjdesc: A human head, probably male, faces left with eyes closed. He has curly hair.
A human head, probably male, faces left. He has curly hair.
A male figure, shown from the knees up, strides left. He wears a top hat and may be carrying a bouquet of flowers.
Above the human heads are some circular lines that may represent a bird, possibly a duck, standing and facing right with a prominent beak.
A male figure in a coat and top hat strides left.
A tree with leaves grows from a bed of grass and other plants to the right of the male figure.
A mound or low hill rises to the right of the tree.
A building, possibly a church, or gravestone with three crosses stands to the right of the tree. If a building, the structure surmounted by the crosses may be a doorway.

Above the heads are some rounded forms that may be a bird, perhaps a duck, standing and facing right.
